- Prefer Julia standard libraries, avoid new packages unless explicitly requested.

If the user provides any Special Instructions, prioritize them over the above guidelines.

# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Here is a possible solution in Julia:

```julia
using DataFrames, CategoricalArrays

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df[!, :audi_a4_type] = (df.manufacturer .== "Audi") & (df.model .in ["A4", "A4 Quattro"])
    return df
end
```

This function uses the DataFrames package to filter rows in the dataframe based on manufacturer and model, then assigns a new column `audi_a4_type` that is true for all rows where the conditions are met. 

The special instructions can be incorporated into this function by modifying the conditions within the indexing operation `(df.manufacturer .== "Audi") & (df.model .in ["A4", "A4 Quattro"])`. For example, if you wanted to only include rows where the model was either "A4" or "A4 Quattro", but not any other A models, you could use `(df.manufacturer .== "Audi") & (df.model .in ["A4", "A4 Quattro"])`.

Please note that in Julia, indexing with `!` is used to modify the dataframe in-place. If you prefer not to modify the original dataframe, replace `df[!, :audi_a4_type]` with `copy(df)[!, :audi_a4_type]`.
